summaryText: Wow, what a powerful message from Pastor Scott Williams about the incredible power of our words! In this sermon, Pastor Scott breaks down the profound truth from Proverbs 18:21 that our tongue has the power of life and death. Can you imagine that every single word we speak has the potential to either build up or tear down? Pastor Scott shares remarkable insights about how our words aren't just sounds, but spiritual forces that can shape our reality. He challenges us to be intentional about speaking life - into ourselves, our situations, and others. From discussing the impact of cursing and negative speech to sharing a hilarious story about a resilient donkey who shook off dirt and climbed out of a well, Pastor Scott delivers a message that's both entertaining and transformative. The sermon reminds us that we're not victims of our circumstances, but architects of our destiny through the words we choose to speak. Whether it's dealing with workplace challenges, family dynamics, or personal struggles, our words can be the catalyst for breakthrough. Pastor Scott's message is a powerful reminder that we have the ability to speak life, shake off negativity, and step into God's abundant promises!
mainPoints: Your talk can help you win
Your talk can lead you to a dead end
Your talk can satisfy you from within

versesMentioned.text: The tongue has the power of life and death, and those who love it will eat its fruit.
And God said, 'Let there be light,' and there was light. God saw that the light was good, and he separated the light from the darkness.

And the Lord God commanded the man, 'You are free to eat from any tree in the garden; but you must not eat from the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, for when you eat from it you will certainly die.'
Do not let any unwholesome talk come out of your mouths, but only what is helpful for building others up according to their needs, that it may benefit those who listen.
You used to walk in these ways, in the life you once lived. But now you must also rid yourselves of all such things as these: anger, rage, malice, slander, and filthy language from your lips.
Those who consider themselves religious and yet do not keep a tight rein on their tongues deceive themselves, and their religion is worthless.
From the fruit of their mouth a person's stomach is filled; with the harvest of their lips they are satisfied.

Monday.scripture: Proverbs 15:1: 'A gentle answer turns away wrath, but a harsh word stirs up anger.'
Monday.action: For one entire day, commit to only speaking words that encourage and build up. Catch yourself before saying anything negative and reframe your thoughts.
Monday.prayer: Lord, help me be mindful of my words today. Let my speech bring life, encouragement, and hope to those around me. Guide my tongue to speak Your truth in love. Amen.

Tuesday.scripture: Proverbs 16:24: 'Gracious words are a honeycomb, sweet to the soul and healing to the bones.'
Tuesday.focus: Understanding the healing power of positive words
Tuesday.action: Write an encouraging letter or message to someone who needs upliftment. Be specific about the good you see in them.
Tuesday.prayer: God, show me someone who needs encouragement today. Give me Your heart and words to speak life into their situation. Help me be an agent of Your healing and hope. Amen.

Wednesday.scripture: Ephesians 4:29: 'Do not let any unwholesome talk come out of your mouths, but only what is helpful for building others up according to their needs, that it may benefit those who listen.'
Wednesday.action: Keep a journal and track every negative or critical statement you make. At the end of the day, reflect on how you can transform those statements into constructive, life-giving words.
Wednesday.prayer: Lord, reveal the areas where my speech does not honor You. Give me wisdom to speak words that build up, not tear down. Transform my mind and heart. Amen.

Thursday.scripture: Psalm 19:14: 'May these words of my mouth and this meditation of my heart be pleasing in your sight, Lord, my Rock and my Redeemer.'
Thursday.action: Practice a 'word fast' - before speaking, pause and ask: 'Is this true? Is this kind? Is this necessary?'
Thursday.prayer: Heavenly Father, guard my mouth and my heart. Help me speak only what is pure, true, and beneficial. Let my words reflect Your love and grace. Amen.

Friday.scripture: Proverbs 12:18: 'The words of the reckless pierce like swords, but the tongue of the wise brings healing.'
Friday.focus: Becoming a source of healing through words
Friday.action: Intentionally speak words of affirmation to three different people. Be specific and genuine in your praise.
Friday.prayer: God, make me an instrument of Your healing. Help me see the potential in others and speak life into their dreams and struggles. Use my words to bring hope and restoration. Amen.

Saturday.scripture: James 3:5: 'Likewise, the tongue is a small part of the body, but it makes great boasts. Consider what a great forest is set on fire by a small spark.'
Saturday.focus: Recognizing the power of small words
Saturday.action: Reflect on past conversations and identify moments where your words significantly impacted someone - positively or negatively. Commit to being more intentional about your speech.
Saturday.prayer: Lord, help me steward the power of my words. Give me wisdom to speak life, hope, and love in every conversation. Make me sensitive to Your Spirit's guidance. Amen.
